review.title: Improving Semantic Composition with Offset Inference
review.abstract: Count-based distributional semantic models suffer from sparsity due to unobserved but plausible co-occurrences in any text collection. This problem is amplified for models like Anchored Packed Trees (APTs), that take the grammatical type of a co-occurrence into account. We therefore introduce a novel form of distributional inference that exploits the rich type structure in APTs and infers missing data by the same mechanism that is used for semantic composition.

metadata.title: Improving Semantic Composition with Offset Inference

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The meaning of a lexeme, characterized as knowledge of coexistence with that lexeme, is represented by a dependent structure of higher order (APT), in which paths are associated with dependencies of higher order linked to weighted lexemes multisets. A key innovation in composition theory is that the type structure of the APT enables the precise arrangement of the semantic representation of the individual lexemes that are put together. However, like other count- based distribution spaces, it is prone to considerable data sparseness caused by the failure to observe all plausible coexistences in the given data.

sections.heading: 2.1 Qualitative Analysis of Offset Representations
sections.text: Each offset view of a lexeme is behaviorally identical to a "normal" lexeme. It has an assigned part of the language, a distributive representation that locates it in semantic space, and we can find neighbors for it, just as we can find neighbors for each other lexem. Thus, a single APT data structure can provide many different views on a given lexem. These views reflect the different ways in which the lexem is used. For example, lawnsubj is also the nsubj-offset representation of the noun law. This lexem is a verb and represents an action carried out by the law. This is in contrast to lawdobj, the dobj-offset representation of the noun law. However, it is also a verb that represents actions done to the law. sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: Distributional inference has its roots in the work of Dagan et al. (1993, 1994), which aims to find probability estimates for invisible words in bigrams and protections (1992, 1998) that use distributional neighbourhood by pooling contexts for word discrimination. Recently, Kober et al. (2016) revived the idea of compositional distribution models (Mitchell and Lapata, 2008, 2010), but these approaches neglect the structure of the text, composition as a commutative operation.A number of approaches proposed in the literature to overcome this deficiency by introducing weighted additive variants (Guevara, 2010, 2011; Zanzotto et al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al., 2010).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced a novel form of distribution conclusion that generalizes the method introduced by Kober et al. (2016). We have demonstrated its effectiveness for semantic composition in two comparative tasks where we have reached the state of the art while maintaining the interpretative capability of our model. Furthermore, we have highlighted an interesting relationship between distribution inference and distribution composition. In future work, we intend to apply our novel method to improve the modelling of selective preferences, lexical conclusions and scaling to longer sentences and whole sentences.
